newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Missing Singapore politician said in Hong Kong.
newsitem.headline: Missing Singapore politician said in Hong Kong.

text.p: A Singapore opposition politician has gone to Hong Kong after fleeing to Malaysia saying his life had been threatened, a Malaysian politician said on Monday.
Workers' Party member Tang Liang Hong was accused by Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong of being a "Chinese chauvinist" during Singapore's election campaign two weeks ago, in which Tang was a candidate.
Tang and his daughter had received threats following Goh's accusations, he and the Workers' Party said.
Tang lost in the no-holds-barred election campaign that halved the opposition presence in Singapore's 83-member parliament from four seats to two.

Malaysia's national Bernama news agency quoted Parti Rakyat Malaysia (Malaysia Peoples' Party) politician Abdul Razak Ahmad as saying: "He (Tang) contacted me from Hong Kong today and said he would be there for about a week."
Abdul Razak said Tang was preparing "documents and evidence" to rebut accusations made against him by Goh's People's Action Party.
Abdul Razak said Tang, whom he has known for more than 30 years since they studied law together, wanted to "expose everything".
Last week, Singapore police urged Tang to help them with their investigation. A police statement said Tang had not handed over one of two threatening letters.
